lines.text: Well?
Well, I ain't gonna go through with it, I tell you.
Now, listen. I never break my word, and I gave my word to Judy - and we're goin' to New England, and we're goin' tonight!
I can't go to New England, not tonight. I'm in the finale.

[offscreen]
Oh, St. Louis! What's the use?
Say, if you don't do like I tell yuh, it's gonna be your finale!

recognizing another inmate, one who apparently caused him to end up in prison]
Jessell!
Well, if it ain't little Morris! So YOU'RE here?
Yes, I'm here. And YOU'RE here, too, where you belong.
Ah, ya' got me all wrong, kid. I lost more money on that horse than YOU did.
Did you, Jessell? Did you lose your position and money and friends? And mother?... She died at my trial. You killed her. If it hadn't been for you...
Shut up, ya' little swine! You were a thief long before I knew ya'!

[Lunges and grabs Jessel]
That's a lie! Take it back! Take it back!

[Jumping in to break it up]
Cut it out! Cut it out!
Go on, scram!
[Shoves Jessel away; Jessel runs off, Morris remains with downcast look on face]
Don't do that... Come on, don't take it so hard.
I can't help it. How did your family feel?

[Pensively pausing]
Well, they don't know. I changed my name... They think I'm in China.
How'd you do that?
Well, I got friends out there. They forward my letters home and cable my folks once a month.
[Loud prison bell rings]
I'll see ya' around. I work in the office over there. I gotta' lot of new fish comin' in. You know - associates, inmates. Come on, son. Buck up, boy.
[Gives Morris a reassuring pat and heads off]

[May and June, twin sisters singing part of "The Prisoner's Song" on the hayride wagon]
'I'll be carried to the new jail tomorrow, Leaving my poor darling alone, With the cold prison bars all around me, And my head on a pillow of stone... '

[Cautioning Steve on why he should not embark on a violent act of vengeance]
Steve, did you ever see a guy go to the 'chair'? Huh? Well, I did. I spent eight months in that Condemned Row. Watched 'em go, one by one. Pals of mine. Guys you'd say 'good morning' to in the morning. And 'good night' to at night. And then they'd go. And I'd wait, day after day, week after week, month after month, wondering if I was gonna' be the next to go.

[Voice rising with emotion]
Let me tell ya', that's no picnic, kid! Listenin' to the drone of that lousy motor and watchin' those lights go dim...

[pauses to let the words sink in]
Steve, come on, don't be a sap.
Steve, you're on the square with Judy, aren't ya'?
You bet I am!
That's all we wanted to know.
